div.p: William K.¬†Wootters

p.span: Department of Physics, Williams College, Williamstown, MA 01267, USA

div.p: Consider an infinite collection of qubits arranged in a line, such that every pair of nearest neighbors is entangled: an ‚Äúentangled chain.‚Äù In this paper we consider entangled chains with translational invariance and ask how large one can make the nearest neighbor entanglement. We find that it is possible to achieve an entanglement of formation equal to 0.285 ebits between each pair of nearest neighbors, and that this is the best one can do under certain assumptions about the state of the chain.

section.h2: 1 Introduction: Example of an entangled chain

div.p: Quantum entanglement has been studied for decades, first because of its importance in the foundations of quantum mechanics, and more recently for its potential technological applications as exemplified by a quantum computer [1]. The new focus has led to a quantitative theory of entanglement [2, 3, 4] that, among other things, allows us to express analytically the degree of entanglement between simple systems [5]. This development makes it possible to pose new quantitative questions about entanglement that could not have been raised before and that promise fresh perspectives on this remarkable phenomenon. In this paper I would like to raise and partially answer such a question, concerning the extent to which a collection of binary quantum objects (qubits) can be linked to each other by entanglement.

Imagine an infinite string of qubits, such as two-level atoms or the spins of spin-1/2 particles. Let us label the locations of the qubits with an integer jùëóitalic-jj that runs from negative infinity to positive infinity. I wish to consider special states of the string, satisfying the following two conditions: (i) each qubit is entangled with its nearest neighbors; (ii) the state is invariant under all translations, that is, under transformations that shift each qubit from its original position jùëóitalic-jj to position j+nùëóùëõitalic-j ADDOP:plus italic-nj+n for some integer nùëõitalic-nn. Let us call a string of qubits satisfying the first condition an entangled chain, and if it also satisfies the second condition, a uniform entangled chain. Note that each qubit need not be entangled with any qubits other than its two nearest neighbors. In this respect an entangled chain is like an ordinary chain, whose links are directly connected only to two neighboring links. By virtue of the translational invariance, the degree of entanglement between nearest neighbors in a uniform entangled chain must be constant throughout the chain. The main question I wish to pose is this: How large can the nearest-neighbor entanglement be in a uniform entangled chain?

This problem belongs to a more general line of inquiry about how entanglement can be shared among more than two objects. Some work on this subject has been done in the context of the cloning of entanglement [6‚Äì11], where one finds limits on the extent to which entanglement can be copied. In a different setting not particularly involving cloning, one finds an inequality bounding the amount of entanglement that a single qubit can have with each of two other qubits [12]. One can imagine more general ‚Äúlaws of entanglement sharing‚Äù that apply to a broad range of configurations of quantum objects. The present work provides further data that might be used to discover and formulate such laws. The specific problem addressed in this paper could also prove relevant for analyzing models of quantum computers in which qubits are arranged along a line, as in an ion trap [13]. The infinite chain can be thought of as an idealization of such a computer. Moreover, the analysis of our question turns out to be interesting in its own right, being related, as we will see, to a familiar problem in many-body physics.

To make the question precise we need a measure of entanglement between two qubits. We will use a reasonably simple and well-justified measure called the ‚Äúconcurrence,‚Äù which is defined as follows [5].
Consider first the case of pure states. A general pure state of two qubits can be written as

div.p: One can verify that such a state is factorizable into single-qubit states‚Äîthat is, it is unentangled‚Äîif and only if Œ±‚Å¢Œ¥=Œ≤‚Å¢Œ≥ùõºùõøùõΩùõæitalic-alpha italic-delta RELOP:equals italic-beta italic-gamma\alpha\delta=\beta\gamma. The quantity C=2‚Å¢|Œ±‚Å¢Œ¥-Œ≤‚Å¢Œ≥|ùê∂2ùõºùõøùõΩùõæitalic-C RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 VERTBAR:| italic-alpha italic-delta ADDOP:minus italic-beta italic-gamma VERTBAR:|C=2|\alpha\delta-\beta\gamma|, which ranges from 0 to 1, is thus a plausible measure of the degree of entanglement. We take this expression as the definition of concurrence for a pure state of two qubits. For mixed states, we define the concurrence to be the greatest convex function on the set of density matrices that gives the correct values for pure states [14].

Though this statement defines concurrence, it does not tell us how to compute it for mixed states. div.p: The best justification for using concurrence as a measure of entanglement comes from a theorem [5] showing that concurrence is a monotonically increasing function of the ‚Äúentanglement of formation,‚Äù which quantifies the non-local resources needed to create the given state [4].111One can define the entanglement of formation as follows. Let œÅùúåitalic-rho\rho be a mixed state of a pair of quantum objects, to be shared between two separated observers who can communicate with each other only via classical signals. The entanglement of formation of œÅùúåitalic-rho\rho is the asymptotic number of singlet states the observers need, per pair, in order to create a large number of pairs in pure states whose average density matrix is œÅùúåitalic-rho\rho. (This is conceptually different from the regularized entanglement of formation, which measures the cost of creating many copies of the mixed state œÅùúåitalic-rho\rho [15]. However, it is conceivable that the two quantities are identical.) Entanglement of formation is conventionally measured in ‚Äúebits,‚Äù and for a pair of binary quantum objects it takes values ranging from 0 to 1 ebit. As mentioned above, the values of Cùê∂italic-CC range from zero to one: an unentangled state has C=0ùê∂0italic-C RELOP:equals NUMBER:0C=0, and a completely entangled state such as the singlet state 12‚Å¢(|01‚ü©-|10‚ü©)12ket01ket10FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ARG:end OPEN:( VERTBAR:| NUMBER:01 CLOSE:rangle ADDOP:minus VERTBAR:| NUMBER:10 CLOSE:rangle CLOSE:)\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|01\rangle-|10\rangle) has C=1ùê∂1italic-C RELOP:equals NUMBER:1C=1. Our problem is to find the greatest possible nearest-neighbor concurrence of a uniform entangled chain. At the end of the calculation we can easily re-express our results in terms of entanglement of formation.

Another issue that needs to be addressed in formulating our question is the meaning of the word ‚Äústate‚Äù as applied to an infinite string of qubits; in particular we need to discuss how such a state is to be normalized. Formally, we can define a state of our system as follows. A state wùë§italic-ww of the infinite string is a function that assigns to every finite set SùëÜitalic-SS of integers a normalized (i.e., trace one) density matrix w‚Å¢(S)ùë§ùëÜitalic-w OPEN:( italic-S CLOSE:)w(S), which we interpret to be the density matrix of the qubits specified by the set SùëÜitalic-SS; moreover the function wùë§italic-ww must be such that if S2subscriptùëÜ2italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endS_{2} is a subset of S1subscriptùëÜ1italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endS_{1}, then w‚Å¢(S2)ùë§subscriptùëÜ2italic-w OPEN:( italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)w(S_{2}) is obtained from w‚Å¢(S1)ùë§subscriptùëÜ1italic-w OPEN:( italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)w(S_{1}) by tracing over the qubits whose labels are not in S2subscriptùëÜ2italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endS_{2}. This formal definition is perfectly sensible but somewhat bulky in practice. In what follows we will usually specify states of the string more informally when it is clear from the informal specification how to generate the density matrix of any finite subset of the string. We will also usually use the symbol œÅùúåitalic-rho\rho instead of w‚Å¢(S)ùë§ùëÜitalic-w OPEN:( italic-S CLOSE:)w(S) to denote the density matrix of a pair of nearest neighbors.

It is not immediately obvious that there exists even a single example of an entangled chain. Note, for example, that the limit of a Schr√∂dinger cat state‚Äîan equal superposition of an infinite string of zeros with an infinite string of ones‚Äîis not an entangled chain. In the cat state, the reduced density matrix of a pair of neighboring qubits is an incoherent mixture of |00‚ü©ket00VERTBAR:| NUMBER:00 CLOSE:rangle|00\rangle and |11‚ü©ket11VERTBAR:| NUMBER:11 CLOSE:rangle|11\rangle, which exhibits a classical correlation but no entanglement. (Note, by the way, that our informal statement ‚Äúan equal superposition of an infinite string of zeros with an infinite string of ones,‚Äù specifies exactly the same state as if we had taken an incoherent mixture of these two infinite strings: no finite set of qubits contains information about the phase of the superposition.)

We can, however, construct a simple example of an entangled chain in the following way. Let w0subscriptùë§0italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{0} be the state such that for each even integer jùëóitalic-jj, the qubits at sites jùëóitalic-jj and j+1ùëó1italic-j ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1j+1 are entangled with each other in a singlet state. We can write this state informally as222Alternatively, we can characterize the state w0subscriptùë§0italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{0} according to our formal definition by specifying the density matrix of each finite collection of qubits: Let SùëÜitalic-SS define such a collection. Then for each even integer jùëóitalic-jj such that both jùëóitalic-jj and j+1ùëó1italic-j ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1j+1 are in SùëÜitalic-SS, the corresponding pair of qubits is in the singlet state; all other qubits (i.e., the unpaired ones) are in the completely mixed state (120012)120012OPEN:( ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end CELL:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end CLOSE:)\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}\frac{1}{2}&0\\ 0&\frac{1}{2}\end{array}\right), and the full density matrix w‚Å¢(S)ùë§ùëÜitalic-w OPEN:( italic-S CLOSE:)w(S) is obtained by taking the tensor product of the pair states and single-qubit states.

div.p: The state w0subscriptùë§0italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{0} is not an entangled chain because the qubits are not entangled with both of their nearest neighbors: qubits at even-numbered locations are not entangled with their neighbors on the left. However, if we let w1subscriptùë§1italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{1} be the state obtained by translating w0subscriptùë§0italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{0} one unit to the left (or to the right‚Äîthe result is the same), and let wùë§italic-ww be an equal mixture of w0subscriptùë§0italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{0} and w1subscriptùë§1italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{1}‚Äîthat is, w=(w0+w1)/2ùë§subscriptùë§0subscriptùë§12italic-w RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) MULOP:divide NUMBER:2w=(w_{0}+w_{1})/2‚Äîthen wùë§italic-ww is a uniform entangled chain, as we now show.

That wùë§italic-ww is translationally invariant follows from the fact that both w0subscriptùë§0italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{0} and w1subscriptùë§1italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{1} are invariant under even displacements and that they transform into each other under odd displacements. Thus we need only show that neighboring states are entangled. For definiteness let us consider the qubits in locations j=1ùëó1italic-j RELOP:equals NUMBER:1j=1 and j=2ùëó2italic-j RELOP:equals NUMBER:2j=2. In the state w0subscriptùë§0italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{0}, the density matrix for these two qubits is

div.p: that is, the singlet state. In the state wùë§italic-ww, the qubits are in an equal mixture of these two density matrices, which is

div.p: It is easy to compute the concurrence of this density matrix, because œÅ~~ùúåOVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-rho ARG:end\tilde{\rho} is the same as œÅùúåitalic-rho\rho itself. The values ŒªisubscriptùúÜùëñitalic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{i} in this case are the eigenvalues of œÅùúåitalic-rho\rho, which are 58,18,18,1858181818FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:5 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:8 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:8 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:8 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:8 ARG:end\frac{5}{8},\frac{1}{8},\frac{1}{8},\frac{1}{8}. The concurrence is therefore C=58-18-18-18=14ùê∂5818181814italic-C RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:5 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:8 ARG:end ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:8 ARG:end ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:8 ARG:end ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:8 ARG:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:endC=\frac{5}{8}-\frac{1}{8}-\frac{1}{8}-\frac{1}{8}=\frac{1}{4}. This same value of the concurrence applies to any other pair of neighboring qubits in the string because of the translational invariance. The fact that the concurrence is non-zero implies that neighboring qubits are entangled, so that the state wùë§italic-ww is indeed an entangled chain. For uniform entangled chains, we will call the common value of Cùê∂italic-CC for neighboring qubits the concurrence of the chain. Thus in the above example the concurrence of the chain is 1414FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end\frac{1}{4}.

As we will see, it is possible to find uniform entangled chains with greater concurrence. Let Cmaxsubscriptùê∂maxitalic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{\rm max} be the least upper bound on the concurrences of all uniform entangled chains. We would like to find this number. We know that Cmaxsubscriptùê∂maxitalic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{\rm max} is no larger than 1, since concurrence never exceeds 1. In fact we can quickly get a somewhat better upper bound, using the following fact: when a qubit is entangled with each of two other qubits, the sum of the squares of the two concurrences is less than or equal to one [12]. In a uniform entangled chain, each qubit must be equally entangled with its two nearest neighbors; so the concurrence with each of them cannot exceed 1/212NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end1/\sqrt{2}. Thus, so far what we know about Cmaxsubscriptùê∂maxitalic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{\rm max} is this:

semantics.annotation: NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PERIOD:.
1/4\leq C_{\rm max}\leq 1/\sqrt{2}.

div.p: This is still a wide range. Most of the rest of this paper is devoted to getting a better fix on Cmaxsubscriptùê∂maxitalic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{\rm max} by explicitly constructing entangled chains.

Using the above example as a model, we will use the following construction to generate other uniform entangled chains. (1) Break the string into blocks of nùëõitalic-nn qubits, and define a state w0subscriptùë§0italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{0} in which each block is in the same nùëõitalic-nn-qubit state |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle; that is, w0subscriptùë§0italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{0} is a tensor product of an infinite number of copies of |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle. (In the above example nùëõitalic-nn had the value 2 and |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle was the singlet state.) (2) Define wksubscriptùë§ùëòitalic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{k}, k=1,‚Ä¶,n-1ùëò1‚Ä¶ùëõ1italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1k=1,\ldots,n-1, to be the state obtained by shifting w0subscriptùë§0italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{0} to the left by kùëòitalic-kk units. (3) Let the final state wùë§italic-ww be the average (w0+‚ãØ+wn-1)/nsubscriptùë§0‚ãØsubscriptùë§ùëõ1ùëõOPEN:( italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus ID:cdots ADDOP:plus italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-n(w_{0}+\cdots+w_{n-1})/n. A state generated in this way will automatically be translationally invariant. In order that the chain have a large concurrence, we will need to choose the state |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle carefully. Finding an optimal |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle and proving that it is optimal may turn out to be a difficult problem. In this paper I will choose |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle according to a strategy that makes sense and may well be optimal but is not proven to be so.

In the final state wùë§italic-ww, each pair of neighboring qubits has the same density matrix because of the translational invariance. Our basic strategy for choosing |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle, described below, is designed to give this neighboring-pair density matrix the following form:

semantics.annotation: italic-rho RELOP:equals OPEN:( ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:11 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end CELL:start italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:22 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end CELL:start italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:23 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end CELL:start italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:23 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end CELL:start italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:33 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: (The ordering of the four basis states is the one given above: |00‚ü©,|01‚ü©,|10‚ü©,|11‚ü©ket00ket01ket10ket11VERTBAR:| NUMBER:00 CLOSE:rangle PUNCT:, VERTBAR:| NUMBER:01 CLOSE:rangle PUNCT:, VERTBAR:| NUMBER:10 CLOSE:rangle PUNCT:, VERTBAR:| NUMBER:11 CLOSE:rangle|00\rangle,|01\rangle,|10\rangle,|11\rangle.) One can show that the concurrence of such a density matrix is simply

semantics.annotation: italic-C RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 VERTBAR:| italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:23 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| PERIOD:.

div.p: Besides making the concurrence easy to compute, the form (8) seems a reasonable goal because it picks out a specific kind of entanglement, namely, a coherent superposition of |01‚ü©ket01VERTBAR:| NUMBER:01 CLOSE:rangle|01\rangle and |10‚ü©ket10VERTBAR:| NUMBER:10 CLOSE:rangle|10\rangle, and limits the ways in which this entanglement can be contaminated or diluted by being mixed with other states. In particular, the form (8) does not allow contamination by an orthogonal entangled state of the form Œ±‚Å¢|00‚ü©+Œ≤‚Å¢|11‚ü©ùõºket00ùõΩket11italic-alpha VERTBAR:| NUMBER:00 CLOSE:rangle ADDOP:plus italic-beta VERTBAR:| NUMBER:11 CLOSE:rangle\alpha|00\rangle+\beta|11\rangle‚Äîorthogonal entangled states when mixed together tend to cancel each other‚Äôs entanglement‚Äîor by the combination of the two unentangled states |00‚ü©ket00VERTBAR:| NUMBER:00 CLOSE:rangle|00\rangle and |11‚ü©ket11VERTBAR:| NUMBER:11 CLOSE:rangle|11\rangle. If the component œÅ44subscriptùúå44italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:44 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\rho_{44} were not equal to zero and the form were otherwise unchanged, the concurrence would be C=max‚Å¢{2‚Å¢(|œÅ23|-œÅ11‚Å¢œÅ44),0}ùê∂max2subscriptùúå23subscriptùúå11subscriptùúå440italic-C RELOP:equals max OPEN:{ NUMBER:2 OPEN:( VERTBAR:| italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:23 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| ADDOP:minus italic-square-root ARG:start italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:11 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:44 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:}C={\rm max}\{2(|\rho_{23}|-\sqrt{\rho_{11}\rho_{44}}),0\}; so it is good to make either œÅ11subscriptùúå11italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:11 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\rho_{11} or œÅ44subscriptùúå44italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:44 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\rho_{44} equal to zero if this can be done without significantly reducing œÅ23subscriptùúå23italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:23 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\rho_{23}. We have chosen to make œÅ44subscriptùúå44italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:44 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\rho_{44} equal to zero.

As it happens, one can guarantee the form (8) for the density matrix of neighboring qubits by imposing the following three conditions on the nùëõitalic-nn-qubit state |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle: (i) |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle is an eigenstate of the operator that counts the number of qubits in the state |1‚ü©ket1VERTBAR:| NUMBER:1 CLOSE:rangle|1\rangle. That is, each basis state represented in |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle must have the same number pùëùitalic-pp of qubits in the state |1‚ü©ket1VERTBAR:| NUMBER:1 CLOSE:rangle|1\rangle. (ii) |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle has no component in which two neighboring qubits are both in the state |1‚ü©ket1VERTBAR:| NUMBER:1 CLOSE:rangle|1\rangle. (iii) The nùëõitalic-nnth qubit is in the state |0‚ü©ket0VERTBAR:| NUMBER:0 CLOSE:rangle|0\rangle. (This last condition effectively extends condition (ii) to the boundary between successive blocks.) Condition (i) guarantees that the density matrix œÅùúåitalic-rho\rho for a pair of nearest neighbors is block diagonal, each block corresponding to a fixed number of 1‚Äôs in the pair. That is, there are two single-element blocks corresponding to |00‚ü©ket00VERTBAR:| NUMBER:00 CLOSE:rangle|00\rangle and |11‚ü©ket11VERTBAR:| NUMBER:11 CLOSE:rangle|11\rangle, and a 2x2 block corresponding to |01‚ü©ket01VERTBAR:| NUMBER:01 CLOSE:rangle|01\rangle and |10‚ü©ket10VERTBAR:| NUMBER:10 CLOSE:rangle|10\rangle. Conditions (ii) and (iii) guarantee that œÅ44subscriptùúå44italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:44 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\rho_{44} is zero. The conditions thus give us the form (8). We impose these three conditions because they seem likely to give the best results; we do not prove that they are optimal.

To illustrate the three conditions and how they can be used, let us consider in detail the case where the block size nùëõitalic-nn is 5 and the number pùëùitalic-pp of 1‚Äôs in each block is 2. (Our strategy does not specify the value of either nùëõitalic-nn or pùëùitalic-pp; these values will ultimately have to be determined by explicit maximization.) In this case, the only basis states our conditions allow in the construction of |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle are |10100‚ü©ket10100VERTBAR:| NUMBER:10100 CLOSE:rangle|10100\rangle, |10010‚ü©ket10010VERTBAR:| NUMBER:10010 CLOSE:rangle|10010\rangle, and |01010‚ü©ket01010VERTBAR:| NUMBER:01010 CLOSE:rangle|01010\rangle. Any other basis state either would have a different number of 1‚Äôs or would violate one of conditions (ii) and (iii). Thus we write

semantics.annotation: VERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:13 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| NUMBER:10100 CLOSE:rangle ADDOP:plus italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:14 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| NUMBER:10010 CLOSE:rangle ADDOP:plus italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:24 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| NUMBER:01010 CLOSE:rangle PERIOD:.
|\xi\rangle=a_{13}|10100\rangle+a_{14}|10010\rangle+a_{24}|01010\rangle.

div.p: The subscripts in ai‚Å¢jsubscriptùëéùëñùëóitalic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{ij} indicate which qubits are in the state |1‚ü©ket1VERTBAR:| NUMBER:1 CLOSE:rangle|1\rangle. The state wùë§italic-ww of the infinite string is derived from |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle as described above. We now want to use Eq.¬†(10) to write the density matrix œÅùúåitalic-rho\rho of a pair of nearest neighbors when the infinite string is in the state wùë§italic-ww. For definiteness let us take the two qubits of interest to be in locations j=1ùëó1italic-j RELOP:equals NUMBER:1j=1 and j=2ùëó2italic-j RELOP:equals NUMBER:2j=2, and let us take the 5-qubit blocks in the state w0subscriptùë§0italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{0} to be given by j=1,‚Ä¶,5ùëó1‚Ä¶5italic-j RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, NUMBER:5j=1,\ldots,5, j=6,‚Ä¶,10ùëó6‚Ä¶10italic-j RELOP:equals NUMBER:6 PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, NUMBER:10j=6,\ldots,10, and so on. Our final density matrix œÅùúåitalic-rho\rho will be an equal mixture of five density matrices, corresponding to the five different displacements of w0subscriptùë§0italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{0} (including the null displacement).

For w0subscriptùë§0italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{0} itself, the qubits at j=1ùëó1italic-j RELOP:equals NUMBER:1j=1 and j=2ùëó2italic-j RELOP:equals NUMBER:2j=2 are the first two qubits of |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle. The density matrix for these two qubits, obtained by tracing out the other three qubits of the block, is

div.p: The density matrix corresponding to w4subscriptùë§4italic-w POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endw_{4} is different in that the two relevant qubits now come from different blocks: the qubit at j=1ùëó1italic-j RELOP:equals NUMBER:1j=1 is the last qubit of one block and the qubit at j=2ùëó2italic-j RELOP:equals NUMBER:2j=2 is the first qubit of the next block. The corresponding density matrix is thus the tensor product of two single-qubit states:

div.p: To get the neighboring-pair density matrix corresponding to our final state wùë§italic-ww, we average the above five density matrices, with the following simple result:

div.p: According to Eq.¬†(9), the concurrence of the pair is

div.p: Continuing with this example‚Äîn=5ùëõ5italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:5n=5 and p=2ùëù2italic-p RELOP:equals NUMBER:2p=2‚Äîlet us find out what values we should choose for a13subscriptùëé13italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:13 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{13}, a14subscriptùëé14italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:14 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{14}, and a24subscriptùëé24italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:24 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{24} in order to maximize Cùê∂italic-CC. First, it is clear that we cannot go wrong by taking each ai‚Å¢jsubscriptùëéùëñùëóitalic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{ij} to be real and non-negative‚Äîany complex phases could only reduce the absolute value in Eq.¬†(15)‚Äîso let us restrict our attention to such values. To take into account the normalization condition, we use a Lagrange multiplier Œ≥/2ùõæ2italic-gamma MULOP:divide NUMBER:2\gamma/2 and extremize the quantity

semantics.annotation: italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:13 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:14 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:14 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:24 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus OPEN:( italic-gamma MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) OPEN:( italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:13 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:14 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:24 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: Differentiating, we arrive at three linear equations expressed by the matrix equation

semantics.annotation: OPEN:( ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:1 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:1 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:1 CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:1 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end CLOSE:) OPEN:( ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:13 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:14 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:24 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-gamma OPEN:( ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:13 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:14 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:24 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

\left(\begin{array}[]{ccc}0&1&0\\ 1&0&1\\ 0&1&0\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}[]{c}a_{13}\\ a_{14}\\ a_{24}\end{array}\right)=\gamma\left(\begin{array}[]{c}a_{13}\\ a_{14}\\ a_{24}\end{array}\right).

div.p: Of the three eigenvalues, only one allows an eigenvector with non-negative components, namely, Œ≥=2ùõæ2italic-gamma RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end\gamma=\sqrt{2}. The normalized eigenvector is

semantics.annotation: OPEN:( ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:13 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:14 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:24 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:( ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ARG:end CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,
\left(\begin{array}[]{c}a_{13}\\ a_{14}\\ a_{24}\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}[]{c}\frac{1}{2}\\ \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\\ \frac{1}{2}\end{array}\right),

div.p: which gives C=2/5=0.283ùê∂250.283italic-C RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:5 RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.283C=\sqrt{2}/5=0.283. This is greater than the value 0.25 that we obtained in our earlier example.

Before generalizing this calculation to arbitrary values of nùëõitalic-nn and pùëùitalic-pp, we adopt some terminology that will simplify the discussion. Let us think of the qubits as ‚Äúsites,‚Äù and let us call the two states of each qubit ‚Äúoccupied‚Äù (|1‚ü©ket1VERTBAR:| NUMBER:1 CLOSE:rangle|1\rangle) and ‚Äúunoccupied‚Äù (|0‚ü©ket0VERTBAR:| NUMBER:0 CLOSE:rangle|0\rangle). The states |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle that we are considering have a fixed number pùëùitalic-pp of occupied sites in a string of nùëõitalic-nn sites; so we can regard the system as a collection of pùëùitalic-pp ‚Äúparticles‚Äù in a one-dimensional lattice of length nùëõitalic-nn. Condition (ii) requires that two particles never be in adjacent sites; it is as if each particle is an extended object, taking up two lattice sites, and two particles cannot overlap. Thus the number of particles is limited by the inequality 2‚Å¢p‚â§n2ùëùùëõNUMBER:2 italic-p RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-n2p\leq n.

section.h2: 3 Generalization to blocks of arbitrary size

div.p: We now turn to the calculation of the optimal concurrence for general nùëõitalic-nn and pùëùitalic-pp assuming our conditions are satisfied. It will turn out that this calculation can be done exactly.
For any values of nùëõitalic-nn and pùëùitalic-pp, the most general form of |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle consistent with condition (i) is

Because of conditions (ii) and (iii), aj1,‚Ä¶,jpsubscriptùëésubscriptùëó1‚Ä¶subscriptùëóùëùitalic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{j_{1},\ldots,j_{p}} must be zero if two of the indices differ by 1 or if jpsubscriptùëóùëùitalic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:endj_{p} has the value nùëõitalic-nn. The coefficients in Eq.¬†(19) satisfy the normalization condition

div.p: Going through the same steps as in the above example, we find that in the state wùë§italic-ww the density matrix of any pair of neighboring sites is

In the above example there were only two such products, a13*‚Å¢a14superscriptsubscriptùëé13subscriptùëé14italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:13 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:14 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{a}_{13}^{*}a_{14} and a14*‚Å¢a24superscriptsubscriptùëé14subscriptùëé24italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:14 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:24 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{a}_{14}^{*}a_{24}; hence the form of Eq.¬†(14).

As before, the concurrence of the chain is equal to 2‚Å¢|œÅ23|2subscriptùúå23NUMBER:2 VERTBAR:| italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:23 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:|2|\rho_{23}|; that is, C=(2/n)‚Å¢|y|ùê∂2ùëõùë¶italic-C RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:2 MULOP:divide italic-n CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| italic-y VERTBAR:|C=(2/n)|y|. The constraints on the new indices krsubscriptùëòùëüitalic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:endk_{r} are simply that 0<k1<k2<‚ãØ<kp<n‚Ä≤0subscriptùëò1subscriptùëò2‚ãØsubscriptùëòùëùsuperscriptùëõ‚Ä≤NUMBER:0 RELOP:less-than italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than ID:cdots RELOP:less-than italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end0<k_{1}<k_{2}<\cdots<k_{p}<n^{\prime}, where n‚Ä≤=n-(p-1)superscriptùëõ‚Ä≤ùëõùëù1italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-n ADDOP:minus OPEN:( italic-p ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:)n^{\prime}=n-(p-1). In effect we have removed from the lattice the site lying to the right of each occupied site. Note that our earlier inequality 2‚Å¢p‚â§n2ùëùùëõNUMBER:2 italic-p RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-n2p\leq n becomes, in terms of n‚Ä≤superscriptùëõ‚Ä≤italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endn^{\prime}, simply p‚â§n‚Ä≤-1ùëùsuperscriptùëõ‚Ä≤1italic-p RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1p\leq n^{\prime}-1, which reflects the fact that the new lattice has only n‚Ä≤-1superscriptùëõ‚Ä≤1italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1n^{\prime}-1 sites. The concurrence is still given by C=(2/n)‚Å¢|y|ùê∂2ùëõùë¶italic-C RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:2 MULOP:divide italic-n CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| italic-y VERTBAR:|C=(2/n)|y|, where

semantics.annotation: italic-y RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-q RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than ID:cdots RELOP:less-than italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than ID:cdots RELOP:less-than italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:[ italic-b POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end SUMOP:product POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r RELOP:not-equals italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] PERIOD:.

y=\sum_{q=1}^{p}\sum_{k_{1}<\cdots<k_{p}}\sum_{k_{1}^{\prime}<\cdots<k_{p}^{% \prime}}\bigg{[}{b}^{*}_{k_{1},\ldots,k_{p}}b_{k_{1}^{\prime},\ldots,k_{p}^{% \prime}}\delta_{k_{q}^{\prime},k_{q}+1}\prod_{r\neq q}\delta_{k_{r}^{\prime},k% _{r}}\bigg{]}.

div.p: We can express yùë¶italic-yy more simply by introducing creation and annihilation operators for each site. We associate with site kùëòitalic-kk the operators

semantics.annotation: italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:( ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:1 CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end CLOSE:) and italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:( ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:1 CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,
c_{k}=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}0&1\\ 0&0\end{array}\right)\,\,{\rm and}\,\,\,c^{\dagger}_{k}=\left(\begin{array}[]{% cc}0&0\\ 1&0\end{array}\right),

div.p: which are represented here in the basis {|0‚ü©,|1‚ü©}ket0ket1OPEN:{ VERTBAR:| NUMBER:0 CLOSE:rangle PUNCT:, VERTBAR:| NUMBER:1 CLOSE:rangle CLOSE:}\{|0\rangle,|1\rangle\}. In terms of these operators, we can write yùë¶italic-yy as

semantics.annotation: italic-y RELOP:equals OPEN:langle italic-zeta VERTBAR:| SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-zeta CLOSE:rangle PERIOD:.
y=\langle\zeta|\sum_{k=1}^{n^{\prime}-2}c^{\dagger}_{k}c_{k+1}|\zeta\rangle.

div.p: Our problem is beginning to resemble the nearest-neighbor tight-binding model for electrons in a one-dimensional lattice. The Hamiltonian for the latter problem‚Äîassuming that the spins of the electrons are all in the same state and can therefore be ignored‚Äîcan be written as333In Eq.¬†(27) the operators cùëêitalic-cc and c‚Ä†superscriptùëê‚Ä†italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endc^{\dagger} are fermionic, whereas those defined in Eq.¬†(25) are not, because they do not anticommute when they are associated with different sites. We could, however, use our cùëêitalic-cc‚Äôs to define genuinely fermionic operators in terms of which the extremization problem has exactly the same form [16].

semantics.annotation: italic-H RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,
H=-\sum_{k=1}^{n^{\prime}-2}(c_{k}^{\dagger}c_{k+1}+c_{k+1}^{\dagger}c_{k}),

div.p: where we have taken the lattice length to be the same as in our problem, namely, n‚Ä≤-1superscriptùëõ‚Ä≤1italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1n^{\prime}-1. From Eqs. (26) and (27) we see that ‚ü®Œ∂|H|Œ∂‚ü©=-2‚Å¢Re‚Å¢(y)quantum-operator-productùúÅùêªùúÅ2Reùë¶OPEN:langle italic-zeta VERTBAR:| italic-H VERTBAR:| italic-zeta CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 Re OPEN:( italic-y CLOSE:)\langle\zeta|H|\zeta\rangle=-2\,{\rm Re}(y). This expectation value is not quite what we need for the concurrence: the concurrence is proportional to the absolute value of yùë¶italic-yy, not its real part. However, as in our earlier example, for the purpose of maximizing Cùê∂italic-CC there is no advantage in straying from real, non-negative values of bk1,‚Ä¶,kpsubscriptùëèsubscriptùëò1‚Ä¶subscriptùëòùëùitalic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:endb_{k_{1},\ldots,k_{p}}. If we restrict our attention to such values, then the absolute value of yùë¶italic-yy is the same as its real part, and we can write the concurrence as

semantics.annotation: italic-C RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-n ARG:end OPEN:langle italic-zeta VERTBAR:| italic-H VERTBAR:| italic-zeta CLOSE:rangle PERIOD:.
C=-\frac{1}{n}\langle\zeta|H|\zeta\rangle.

div.p: Thus, maximizing the concurrence amounts to minimizing the expectation value of Hùêªitalic-HH, that is, finding the ground state energy of the tight-binding model, as long as the ground state involves only real and non-negative values of bk1,‚Ä¶,kpsubscriptùëèsubscriptùëò1‚Ä¶subscriptùëòùëùitalic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:endb_{k_{1},\ldots,k_{p}}.

The one-dimensional tight-binding model is in fact easy to solve [16, 17]. Its ground state is the discrete analogue of the ground state of a collection of pùëùitalic-pp non-interacting fermions in a one-dimensional box. In our case the ‚Äúwalls‚Äù of the box, where the wavefunction goes to zero, are at k=0ùëò0italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:0k=0 and k=n‚Ä≤ùëòsuperscriptùëõ‚Ä≤italic-k RELOP:equals italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endk=n^{\prime}, and the ground state |Œ∂0‚ü©ketsubscriptùúÅ0VERTBAR:| italic-zeta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle|\zeta_{0}\rangle is given by the following antisymmetrized product of sine waves:

semantics.annotation: italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:proportional-to caligraphic-A OPEN:[ TRIGFUNCTION:sine OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-pi italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) TRIGFUNCTION:sine OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) ID:cdots TRIGFUNCTION:sine OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-p italic-pi italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) CLOSE:] PERIOD:.

b_{k_{1},\ldots,k_{p}}\propto{\mathcal{A}}\Big{[}\sin\Big{(}\frac{\pi k_{p}}{n% ^{\prime}}\Big{)}\sin\Big{(}\frac{2\pi k_{p-1}}{n^{\prime}}\Big{)}\cdots\sin% \Big{(}\frac{p\pi k_{1}}{n^{\prime}}\Big{)}\Big{]}.

div.p: Here ùíúùíúcaligraphic-A{\mathcal{A}} indicates the operation of antisymmetrizing over the indices k1,‚Ä¶,kpsubscriptùëò1‚Ä¶subscriptùëòùëùitalic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:endk_{1},\ldots,k_{p}. In the range of values we are allowing for these indices, that is, 0<k1<k2<‚ãØ<kp<n‚Ä≤0subscriptùëò1subscriptùëò2‚ãØsubscriptùëòùëùsuperscriptùëõ‚Ä≤NUMBER:0 RELOP:less-than italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than ID:cdots RELOP:less-than italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end0<k_{1}<k_{2}<\cdots<k_{p}<n^{\prime}, the coefficients bk1,‚Ä¶,kpsubscriptùëèsubscriptùëò1‚Ä¶subscriptùëòùëùitalic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:endb_{k_{1},\ldots,k_{p}} are indeed non-negative, so that Eq.¬†(28) is valid.

The ground state energy, from which we can find the concurrence, is simply the sum of the first pùëùitalic-pp single-particle eigenvalues of Hùêªitalic-HH. There are exactly n‚Ä≤-1superscriptùëõ‚Ä≤1italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1n^{\prime}-1 such eigenvalues, one for each dimension of the single-particle subspace; they are given by

semantics.annotation: italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 TRIGFUNCTION:cosine OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-m italic-pi ARG:end ARG:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-m RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, ID:ldots PUNCT:, italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 PERIOD:.
E_{m}=-2\cos\Big{(}\frac{m\pi}{n^{\prime}}\Big{)},\,\,m=1,\ldots,n^{\prime}-1.

div.p: Thus the concurrence is

semantics.annotation: italic-C RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-n ARG:end OPEN:langle italic-zeta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-H VERTBAR:| italic-zeta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ARG:start italic-n ARG:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end TRIGFUNCTION:cosine OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-m italic-pi ARG:end ARG:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.
C=-\frac{1}{n}\langle\zeta_{0}|H|\zeta_{0}\rangle=\frac{2}{n}\sum_{m=1}^{p}% \cos\Big{(}\frac{m\pi}{n^{\prime}}\Big{)}.

div.p: Doing the sum is straightforward, with the following result:

semantics.annotation: italic-C RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-n ARG:end OPEN:[ FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start TRIGFUNCTION:cosine OPEN:( italic-p italic-pi MULOP:divide italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus TRIGFUNCTION:cosine OPEN:( OPEN:( italic-p ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) italic-pi MULOP:divide italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus TRIGFUNCTION:cosine OPEN:( italic-pi MULOP:divide italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus TRIGFUNCTION:cosine OPEN:( italic-pi MULOP:divide italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ARG:end CLOSE:] PERIOD:.
C=\frac{1}{n}\Bigg{[}\frac{\cos(p\pi/n^{\prime})-\cos((p+1)\pi/n^{\prime})+% \cos(\pi/n^{\prime})-1}{1-\cos(\pi/n^{\prime})}\Bigg{]}.

div.p: Recall that n‚Ä≤=n-p+1superscriptùëõ‚Ä≤ùëõùëù1italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-n ADDOP:minus italic-p ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1n^{\prime}=n-p+1. Eq. (32) gives the largest value of Cùê∂italic-CC consistent with our conditions, for fixed values of nùëõitalic-nn and pùëùitalic-pp. Note, for example, that when n=5ùëõ5italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:5n=5 and p=2ùëù2italic-p RELOP:equals NUMBER:2p=2, Eq. (32) gives C=2/5ùê∂25italic-C RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:5C=\sqrt{2}/5, just as we found before for this case.

We still need to optimize over nùëõitalic-nn and pùëùitalic-pp. It is best to make the block size nùëõitalic-nn very large‚Äîany state wùë§italic-ww that is possible with block size nùëõitalic-nn is also allowed by block size 2‚Å¢n2ùëõNUMBER:2 italic-n2n‚Äîso we take the limit as nùëõitalic-nn goes to infinity. Let Œ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha be the density of occupied sites‚Äîthat is, Œ±=p/nùõºùëùùëõitalic-alpha RELOP:equals italic-p MULOP:divide italic-n\alpha=p/n‚Äîand let nùëõitalic-nn approach infinity with Œ±ùõºitalic-alpha\alpha held fixed. In this limit, the concurrence becomes

semantics.annotation: italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start lim POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ARG:start italic-pi ARG:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-alpha CLOSE:) TRIGFUNCTION:sine OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-alpha italic-pi ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-alpha ARG:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.
C_{\rm lim}=\frac{2}{\pi}(1-\alpha)\sin\Big{(}\frac{\alpha\pi}{1-\alpha}\Big{)}.

div.p: Taking the derivative, one finds that Climsubscriptùê∂limitalic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start lim POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{\rm lim} is maximized when

semantics.annotation: TRIGFUNCTION:tangent OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-alpha italic-pi ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-alpha ARG:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-pi ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-alpha ARG:end PUNCT:,
\tan\Big{(}\frac{\alpha\pi}{1-\alpha}\Big{)}=\frac{\pi}{1-\alpha},

div.p: which happens at Œ±=0.300844ùõº0.300844italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.300844\alpha=0.300844, where Clim=0.434467subscriptùê∂lim0.434467italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start lim POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.434467C_{\rm lim}=0.434467. This is the highest value of concurrence that is consistent with our method of constructing the state of the chain and with our three conditions on |Œæ‚ü©ketùúâVERTBAR:| italic-xi CLOSE:rangle|\xi\rangle. Note that it is considerably larger than what we got in our first example, in which a string of singlets was mixed with a shifted version of the same string‚Äîone might call this earlier construction the ‚Äúbicycle chain‚Äù state. Unlike the bicycle chain state, our best state breaks the symmetry between the basis states |0‚ü©ket0VERTBAR:| NUMBER:0 CLOSE:rangle|0\rangle and |1‚ü©ket1VERTBAR:| NUMBER:1 CLOSE:rangle|1\rangle: the fraction of qubits in the state |1‚ü©ket1VERTBAR:| NUMBER:1 CLOSE:rangle|1\rangle is about 30% rather than 50%. Of course the entanglement would be just as large if the roles of |1‚ü©ket1VERTBAR:| NUMBER:1 CLOSE:rangle|1\rangle and |0‚ü©ket0VERTBAR:| NUMBER:0 CLOSE:rangle|0\rangle were reversed.
It is interesting to ask what value of entanglement of formation the above value of concurrence corresponds to. As a function of the concurrence, the entanglement of formation is given by

semantics.annotation: italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-h OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-C POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,
E_{f}=h\bigg{(}\frac{1+\sqrt{1-C^{2}}}{2}\bigg{)},

div.p: where h‚Ñéitalic-hh is the binary entropy function h‚Å¢(x)=-[x‚Å¢log2‚Å°x+(1-x)‚Å¢log2‚Å°(1-x)]‚Ñéùë•delimited-[]ùë•subscript2ùë•1ùë•subscript21ùë•italic-h OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus OPEN:[ italic-x OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-x ADDOP:plus OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-x CLOSE:) OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-x CLOSE:) CLOSE:]h(x)=-[x\log_{2}x+(1-x)\log_{2}(1-x)]. For the above value of concurrence, one finds that the entanglement of formation is Ef=0.284934subscriptùê∏ùëì0.284934italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.284934E_{f}=0.284934 ebits. (For the bicycle chain state, the entanglement of formation between neighboring pairs is only 0.118 ebits.)

If one can prove that this value is optimal, then it can serve as a reference point for interpreting entanglement values obtained for real physical systems. A string of spin-1/2 particles interacting via the antiferromagnetic Heisenberg interaction, for example, has eigenstates that typically have some non-zero nearest-neighbor entanglement. It would be interesting to find out how the entanglements appearing in these states compare to the maximum possible entanglement for a string of qubits.444Since the original version of this paper was written, the question about the antiferromagnetic Heisenberg chain has been answered for the ground state [18]: though the nearest-neighbor concurrence of the ground state is high (C=0.386ùê∂0.386italic-C RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.386C=0.386), it is not optimal.

Clearly the problem we have analyzed here can be generalized. One can consider a two or three-dimensional lattice of qubits and ask how entangled the neighboring qubits can be. If we were to analyze these cases using assumptions similar to those we have made in the one-dimensional case, we would again find the problem reducing to a many-body problem, but with less tractable interactions. Assuming that pairwise entanglement tends to diminish as the total entanglement is shared among more particles, one expects the optimal values of Cùê∂italic-CC and Efsubscriptùê∏ùëìitalic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{f} to shrink as the dimension of the lattice increases.
I would like to thank Kevin O‚ÄôConnor for many valuable discussions on distributed entanglement.
